questions.text: A 34 yrs old pregnant female came to obs OPD to check for malformation in her baby. Which of the following congenital malformations can be detected the earliest by USG?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anencephaly Anencephaly, holoprosencephaly and ventral wall defects (e.g. ectopia cordis, omphalocele, bladder extrophy) have a very high rate of detection in the first trimester.

Highyeild:

Some Indications for First-Trimester Ultrasound Examination Confirm an intrauterine pregnancy Evaluate a suspected ectopic pregnancy Define the cause of vaginal bleeding Evaluate pelvic pain, estimate gestational age, Diagnose or evaluate multifetal gestations Confirm cardiac activity Assist chorionic villus sampling, embryo transfer, and localization and removal of an intrauterine device Assess for certain fetal anomalies, such as anencephaly, in high-risk patients Evaluate maternal pelvic masses and/or uterine abnormalities Measure nuchal translucency when part of a screening program for fetal aneuploidy Evaluate suspected gestational trophoblastic disease

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Rest of the anomalies can be detected in the second trimester, hence options (a,b,d) are incorrect. Recent MTP act amendment allows termination of anencephaly irrespective of gestation

Extraedge:

Anencephaly is the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp that occurs during embryonic development. It is a cephalic disorder that results from a neural tube defect that occurs when the rostral (head) end of the neural tube fails to close, usually between the 23rd and 26th day following conception.

questions.text: A 32 year-old female with a previous history of anencephaly in a child is scheduled to undergo a screening ultrasound for ruling out anencephaly in her current pregnancy. What is the earliest gestational age at which she can be screened?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10-12 weeks Anencephaly can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation, as the detection rates are very higher at this time

Highyeild:

Anencephaly is an open defect in the calvaria and skin, such that the cranial neural tube is exposed. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "Frog-eye sign". Anencephaly is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. 12-14 weeks Option C. 14-16 weeks Option D. 16-18 weeks A nencephaly can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation, as the detection rates are very higher at this time ,so other options are incorrect

Extraedge:

There are three types of anencephaly : (1) meroanencephaly, where there is rudimentary brain tissue and partial formation of the cranium; (2) holoanencephaly, the most common type, in which the brain is completely absent, and (3) craniorachischisis, the most severe, where area cerebrovasculosa and area medullovasculosa

questions.text: You notice the following finding on the transvaginal USG of a woman with amenorrhea. What is the earliest gestational age at which this can be detected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5-6 weeks The given transvaginal ultrasound shows a gestational sac. This can be identified by transvaginal USG at 5 weeks Cardiac activity in an embryo can be identified at 6 weeks.

Highyeild:

The gestational sac is the large cavity of fluid surrounding the embryo. During early embryogenesis it consists of the extraembryonic coelom , also called the chorionic cavity . The gestational sac is normally contained within the uterus. It is the only available structure that can be used to determine if an intrauterine pregnancy exists until the embryo can be identified. On obstetric ultrasound, the gestational sac is a dark (anechoic) space surrounded by a white (hyperechoic) rim.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. 7-8 week Option C. 3-4 weeks Option D. 9-12 weeks The given transvaginal ultrasound shows a gestational sac. This can be identified by transvaginal USG at 5 weeks ,so other options are incorrect

Extraedge:

During embryogenesis, the extraembryonic coelom (or chorionic cavity ) that constitutes the gestational sac is a portion of the conceptus consisting of a cavity between Heuser's membrane and the trophoblast. During formation of the primary yolk sac, some of the migrating hypoblast cells differentiate into mesenchymal cells that fill the space between Heuser's membrane and the trophoblast, forming the extraembryonic mesoderm . As development progresses, small lacunae begin to form within the extraembryonic mesoderm which enlarges to become the extraembryonic coelom.

questions.text: A G2P1 female at 24 weeks of pregnancy undergoes ultrasound examination for size of uterus larger than her dates. Her AFI as seen on us is 28 cms and ultrasound shows a cystic mass in centre of her abdomen and another cystic mass on right side as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely associated condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Downs syndrome Double bubble sign represents Duodenal atresia

Highyeild:

It is characterized by the sonographic double-bubble sign, which represents distention of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum Approximately 30 percent of affected fetuses have an associated chromosomal abnormality or genetic syndrome, particularly trisomy 21(DOWN SYNDROME) . Of cases without a genetic abnormality, a third have associated anomalies, most commonly cardiac defects and other gastrointestinal abnormalities

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Gestational diabetes Option C. Twin pregnancy Option D. Hydrops fetalis Double bubble sign represents Duodenal atresia,hence other options are ruled out.

Extraedge:

Down syndrome is a genetic condition where a person is born with an extra copy of chromosome 21. This means that they have a total of 47 chromosomes instead of 46. This can affect how their brain and body develop

questions.text: A young girl with primary amenorrhea is being evaluated for the presence of a congenital uterine anomaly. What is the gold standard investigation to detect the same?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRI MRI is the gold standard in detecting congenital uterine anomalies, It is the most accurate imaging technique for investigating and classifying congenital uterine anomalies and is hence considered to be the gold standard. Classifying congenital uterine anomalies is important as fertility outcomes and surgical management vary considerably.

Highyeild:

MR imaging provides clear delineation of both the internal and external uterine anatomy and has a reported accuracy of up to 100 percent for müllerian anomaly evaluation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - USG is the primary/initial investigation done. However, not all uterine anomalies can be detected and classified. Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is also done, however it cannot differentiate between a septate and bicornuate uterus, as only the uterine interior is visualized, leading to similar images on HSG. CT and X-ray are not preferred, and in case of suspected pregnancy they are avoided.

Extraedge:

Major ligaments The uterus is held in place by several peritoneal ligaments , of which the following are the most important (there are two of each): Name From To Uterosacral ligaments Posterior cervix Anterior face of sacrum Cardinal ligaments Side of the cervix Ischial spines Pubocervical ligaments [15] Side of the cervix Pubic symphysis

questions.text: A woman presents at 33-weeks of gestation and the umbilical artery Doppler imaging shows the following finding. What is the next step of management?

options.label: C
options.text: Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate termination of pregnancy The umbilical artery Doppler depicts reversal of end-diastolic flow or REDF (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. As the period of gestation has exceeded 32 weeks, the pregnancy can be terminated.

Highyeild:

In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but don't appear below it. This suggests a fetal compromise, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >34 weeks. Reversed end-diastolic flow (REDF) suggests impending fetal death, hence the pregnancy is terminated by C-section if >32 weeks.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Continue pregnancy till term Option C. Terminate the pregnancy at 34 weeks of gestation Option D. Continue steroids until term The umbilical artery Doppler depicts reversal of end-diastolic flow or REDF (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. Immediate termination of pregnancy should be the next best step in this case.

Extraedge:

According to Zelop and colleagues (1996), the perinatal mortality rate for absent end-diastolic flow was about 10 percent, and for reversed end-diastolic flow, it approximated 33 percent.

questions.text: A G1PO female underwent an USG at 13 weeks of pregnancy. USG examination shows twin pregnancy. Which of the following statements is true for the twin pregnancy shown in image?

options.label: A
options.text: Should be delivered by c section

options.label: C
options.text: Occurs when MZ twin divide between 4-8 days

options.label: D
options.text: M/c complication of the condition is TTTS

questions.correct_answer: A. Should be delivered by c section
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Should be delivered by c section In monochorionic pregnancy, the chorion does not extend between the layers of the intertwin membrane. Thus, the inter-twin membrane comes to an abrupt halt in a T-configuration at the edge of the amniotic sac.

Highyeild:

In contrast, in a dichorionic pregnancy, the sonographic image depicts a 'twin-peak' sign or the 'lambda sign" as the Chorion is present between the intertwin membrane. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen inserted between the amniochorion layers. TTTS occurs in MCDA; not MCMA

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Associated with dizygotic twin gestation - This case is associated with monochorionic pregnancy Option C. Occurs when MZ twin divide between 4-8 days Option D. M/c complication of the condition is TTTS - TTTS occurs in MCDA; not MCMA

Extraedge:

Timing of elective delivery after conservative management of a late second- or early third-trimester single fetal death is debatable. Dichorionic twins can probably be safely delivered at term. Monochorionic twin gestations are more difficult to manage and are often delivered between 34 and 37 weeks’ gestation

questions.text: Primigravida, 2 months amenorrhea. Pulse 80/min. BP =120/80. Hb=11 gm%. USG findings are as shown. Incorrect about USG findings

options.label: A
options.text: Ring of fire sign is seen

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Live intrauterine pregnancy USG features An empty uterine cavity or no evidence of an intrauterine pregnancy Solid hyperechoic mass is possible but non-specific

Highyeild:

The fertilised egg can't survive outside the uterus . If left to grow, it may damage nearby organs and cause life-threatening loss of blood. Symptoms include pelvic pain and vaginal bleeding. To prevent complications, treatment is required. In the early stages, medication may be sufficient. Later stages require surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Tubal ring sign Ring of fire sign: can be seen on colour Doppler in a tubal ectopic, but can also be seen in a corpus luteum An absence of colour Doppler flow does not exclude an ectopic Free pelvic fluid or hemoperitoneum in the pouch of Douglas

Extraedge:

Early signs of an ectopic pregnancy include: Upset stomach and vomiting Sharp belly cramps Pain on one side of your body Dizziness or weakness Pain in your shoulder, neck, or rectum

questions.text: The pelvic ultrasound of a 35-year-old woman is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Monochorionic twins The given image shows the 'T-sign' seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. In monochorionic pregnancy, the chorion does not extend between the layers of the intertwin membrane. Thus, the inter-twin membrane comes to an abrupt halt in a T-configuration at the edge of the amniotic sac.

Highyeild:

The 3 types are: dichorionic diamniotic (DCDA) twins – each has their own separate placenta and separate sac. monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) twins – share a single placenta but have their own separate sacs. monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) twins – share both a placenta and a sac – this is a much rarer type of pregnancy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - In contrast, in a dichorionic pregnancy, the sonographic image depicts a 'twin-peak' sign or the 'lambda sign" as the Chorion is present between the intertwin membrane. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen inserted between the amniochorion layers.

Extraedge:

Fraternal or 'dizygotic' twins Two separate eggs (ova) are fertilised by two separate sperm, resulting in fraternal or 'dizygotic' (two-cell) twins. These babies will be no more alike than siblings born at separate times. The babies can be either the same sex or different sexes, with the odds roughly equal for each.

questions.text: A 24 yr old patient came to OPD with complains of not able to conceive Husband semen analysis was normal. HSG was ordered. What is the diagnosis based on the given image
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unicornuate uterus The given image shows the hysterosalpingogram of a unicornuate uterus. If this anomaly is suspected, 3-D sonography increases diagnostic accuracy, but again MR imaging may be preferred.

Highyeild:

During typical fetal development, two tubelike structures, called the Mullerian ducts, fuse together to create the uterus. The upper portions form the fallopian tubes. If one of the ducts fails to develop, it may result in a single-horned uterus, called a unicornuate uterus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - The endometrial cavity usually assumes a fusiform (banana type) shape, tapering at the apex and draining into a single fallopian tube. The uterus is generally shifted off the midline. Bicornuate uterus has 2 cornua; but single cervix; while didelphus uterus has 2 cervices, hence other options are excluded

Extraedge:

Rudimentary horns also increase the risk for an ectopic pregnancy within the remnant, which may be disastrous. This risk includes noncommunicating cavitary rudiments, for which transperitoneal sperm migration permits ovum fertilization and pregnancy

questions.text: Primigravida, 2 months amenorrhea. On USG, uterus is empty, there is adnexal mass of 2.5 × 3 cm and B-hCG titer of 1500 mIU/mL. Pulse 80/min. BP =120/80. Hb=11 gm%. What modality of treatment is MOST suitable for Her
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medical management(MTX) Given clinical history and imaging made diagnosis of unreported ectopic pregnancy Management should be medical USG Features An empty uterine cavity or no evidence of an intrauterine pregnancy Solid hyperechoic mass is possible but non-specific Tubal ring sign colour Ring of fire sign: can be seen on colour Doppler in a tubal ectopic, but can also be seen in a corpus luteum An absence of Doppler flow does not exclude an ectopic Free pelvic fluid or hemoperitoneum in the pouch of Douglas
